quote: But it all hinges on how you interpret an ancient text that's been translated and re-translated over the centuries... words that were couched in metaphor to begin with. I'm sorry, Major... but where you see a Sword of Stars, I see a comet. Where you see vipers, I see three scientists. And where you see the Emissary... I see a Starfleet Officer.
Dax to Sisko.
Go ahead.
We're ready to deploy the relay.
I'm on my way.
... all right, now we just have to shunt the ODN line through the secondary field coils.
We can't do that.
Why not?
The coils aren't configured to handle ODN output...
Why not? Did you modify them, too?
Actually I replaced them. They were always shorting out on us. Frankly I don't see how this station kept running during the occupation.
Why didn't you tell me you'd replaced the field coils?
If you'd let me know what you were planning to do, I would have.
I don't have time to explain everything.
What, you think I won't be able to understand what you're doing?
It's been my experience that...
What... that humans aren't good engineers?
No, not humans. Males.
I beg your pardon?
Men just don't seem to have a head for this sort of thing... that's why women dominate the sciences.
Maybe on Cardassia. But on this station, this man is Chief of Operations. I know these systems better than anyone -- including you.
I think I know what the problem is... so if you want to get their transceiver on line, hand me that laser-torch and give me some room.
Gilora and Chief O'Brien should have their transceiver on-line by now.
Are we ready on this end?
Almost... I'm just about to activate the relay's transmission array.
Dejar... ?
Standing by...
I'm receiving the relay's test signal.
(to Sisko; with a smile) I'd say we're ready to send the first message through the wormhole.
Target the signaling array toward the wormhole and initiate a carrier wave in the delta band frequency...
Initiating carrier wave...
If they receive it on the station, they'll send an acknowledging signal on the same frequency.
I'm not receiving anything...
Then we have to assume it didn't work. Let's try the theta band frequency.
Initiating carrier wave...
Something's wrong... I'm picking up a neutrino surge from the wormhole...
Report.
Somehow the carrier wave caused the wormhole to open...
The wormhole's gravity well has increased by a factor of three...
Terminate the carrier wave and maintain our position...
Gravimetric fields have returned to normal...
What happened?
I'm not sure... the carrier wave shouldn't have affected the wormhole at all.
Was there any damage to the relay?
None... I'm still receiving the test signal.
Benjamin... the gravitational surge altered the course of the comet... It's now heading directly toward the wormhole...
If the comet enters the wormhole, the silithium in its core will cause a cascade reaction.
And collapse the wormhole... permanently.
Commander's Log, Supplemental. With less than five hours before the comet reaches the wormhole, I've brought the Defiant back to the station and convened a meeting of the entire science team.
Apparently the carrier wave we sent created some sort of subspace inversion in the wormhole.
That's what caused the gravity well to form.
The possibility of subspace inversion was predicted in one of our computer models...
That wasn't included in the data you sent us.
The probability of such an occurrence was less than two percent... well within safety limitations. So we saw no reason to include it in the data we sent you.
It would seem our scientific methodologies differ slightly.
It's our practice to examine all possibilities, no matter how unlikely, before we proceed with field tests.

We would, of course, prefer to operate that way as well... however since the Science Ministry falls under the jurisdiction of the military, we have to follow certain rules. One of them is not to make any project look... "unnecessarily" dangerous.
We'll have to keep that in mind when we resume work on the communications relay.
That is an extremely unlikely possibility, Commander. The Science Ministry will undoubtedly want to... (glances at Ulani and Gilora) -- assemble a new team, before proceeding further.
That is, of course, an internal Cardassian matter.
Chief... Dax feels that we can't risk using tractor beams to deflect the comet.
It would probably break up into smaller pieces and we'd have a bigger mess on our hands.
The same thing would happen if you tried to destroy it with a phaser beam.
Not necessarily. I could modify the Defiant's phaser array to generate a beam wide enough to encompass the entire comet.
Vaporizing it evenly so it won't break up.
How long would the modifications take?
Three hours.
Get on it. We'll be cutting this pretty close.
-- I've accessed the Defiant's primary phaser relay...
I'm going to try shunting it through the warp drive...
Won't that overload the relay?
Not if we bypass the plasma emitter...
I hadn't thought of that...
The emitter coupling is over there...
What are you doing now... ?
I'm decoupling the servos so they won't lock up...
You have very steady hands...
They get the job done, I guess...
And right now, the most important job is bypassing the plasma emitter...
I assure you I'm quite fertile...
I could provide you with many healthy children, if that's your concern... but, frankly I think you're getting a little ahead of yourself.
Children? What are you talking about? I already have a child. And a wife.
You're married?
Yes, happily.
Then why have you been leading me to believe that you wanted me?
I haven't been. All we've done since we met is argue.
And I took your overt irritability toward me as a signal that you were interested in pursuing a physical relationship.
That may be how Cardassians do things, but not humans.
It seems this is a case of cross- cultural misunderstanding.
Yes, it does. I'm not even remotely interested in you. (realizing how that sounds) That's not what I meant. You're very attractive... and I'm flattered, of course...
There's no need to continue, Mister O'Brien... you've made your feelings clear...
Gilora, wait. We need to finish this.
I'm sure you can complete the work on your own...
Chief O'Brien said he'd have the modifications to the Defiant's phasers ready within half an hour.
Half an hour ahead of schedule...
The chief is a born engineer. He always gives himself a comfortable margin on his repair estimates.
Let me guess... you're reading up on Bajoran prophecies concerning the Emissary...
There are hundreds of them. Most of them are vague... some are contradictory... but there's just enough truth in a few of them to make me wonder...
You mean some of them have come true?
If you interpret them a certain way, yes.
And so now you're wondering if Trakor's prophecy is coming true as well...
I have to admit it's getting harder to ignore.
But Benjamin, there's every reason to believe we'll be able to destroy the comet.
I know... but I'm becoming more and more concerned that if I don't send the Cardassians home, something else will go wrong...
And the "gates of heaven will burn and be cast open... "
Let me ask you something... what would you do if you'd never heard Trakor's prophecy?
I'd continue working on the communications relay.
Then it seems to me you have a choice: you can either make your own decisions... or you can let these prophecies make them for you.
As soon as the Defiant's ready, have the Cardassians meet us on board.
The comet's directly ahead. Distance... two hundred kilometers.
Bring us to within ten kilometers. Chief... are your phaser modifications on-line?
Aye, Sir. Phasers are locked on target.
Holding position at ten kilometers.
Shields up... go to Red Alert.
Fire...
What the hell happened, Chief?
I don't know, sir... the entire weapons relay just blew out... all defensive systems are down.
Benjamin, sensors show that the modified phasers never came on-line -- we fired a standard burst and it shattered the comet instead of vaporizing it.
There's no way they should have misfired like that. I modified the systems myself.
Commander, the three fragments are still on course for the wormhole...
How long until they reach the entrance?
Twenty six minutes...
And without weapons... we have no way of stopping them...
The main emitter coupling has been depolarized... I must've accidentally inverted the power flow when I was trying to modify the phaser array.
I can't believe it... a first year Engineering student wouldn't make a mistake like that...
This wasn't your fault, Mister O'Brien... and it wasn't an accident.
Gilora...
Dejar is a member of the Obsidian Order... she was assigned to our team for "security" reasons. I think she sabotaged the coupling.

The Order has always been opposed to the peace treaty with Bajor. So they sent you to sabotage the relay... because if the first joint venture between Cardassia and Bajor was a failure, it would probably be the last.
That's all speculation, Commander... you have no proof.
If it was sabotage, a DNA scan of the coupling will probably reveal who was responsible.
Take her to quarters and detain her there.
Now that the comet's been fractured into smaller pieces, can we use the tractor beams to deflect them?
They'd just disintegrate further, releasing more silithium.
If we can't stop the fragments, is there any way we can prevent the silithium from interacting with the wormhole?
Maybe if we could contain it, somehow...
If you can generate a subspace field around the fragments, that might contain the silithium.
The warp drive... it could create a subspace bubble around the ship...
But we'd have to maneuver the Defiant between the fragments... they're so close together, there's not enough room...
A shuttlepod could maneuver between them... and its warp drive should be able to create a large enough subspace field...
Maybe... but it could overload the engines.
That's a chance I'll have to take.
Major, you have the bridge. Take the Defiant back to the Alpha Quadrant as soon as I've cleared the shuttlebay.
Commander, I'd like to go with you.
Not just because I'm your first officer... but because I believe I'm here to help the Emissary.
Dax, the Bridge is yours.
We've cleared the shuttlebay... signal the Defiant that they can leave...
They're heading for the wormhole...
I'm going to take us in behind the comet fragments... it'll be easier to maneuver into position...
Hold position here... they could be in for a rough ride. Stand by transporters in case we need to beam them off the shuttlepod when they clear the wormhole.
We're in position... activate the subspace field...
Field engaged...
We'll reach the entrance to the wormhole in... five seconds...
The subspace field is losing integrity... some of the silithium is starting to leak through...
Divert power from the engines to the subspace field coils... we'll let our own inertia carry us the rest of the way.
That helped... but we're still losing silithium...
I'm picking up a neutrino surge... something's coming through.
Dax to Sisko...
Sisko, here.
Are you all right, Benjamin?
There was some silithium leakage inside the wormhole... but we're fine.
I don't believe it.
What is it, Chief?
I'm picking up the test signal from the communications relay...
How is that possible?
I'm not sure... I'm reading a subspace filament leading back through the wormhole... it's acting almost like a carrier wave...
The comet fragments... they left a trail of silithium in the wormhole.
The silithium particles must have interacted with the wormhole's ambient radiation...
And created the filament...
It's almost like the wormhole's been wedged open just a crack... enough to let subspace signals through...
The prophecy came true... all of it... we just misinterpreted Trakor's words...
The three vipers... he wasn't talking about the Cardassians... he meant the three comet fragments...
The communications relay... in a sense we've been trying to "peer through the temple gates... "
The silithium ignited the wormhole... burning the temple gates...
So that they'd never close again...
And it's all because the Emissary used the Sword of Stars...
And Trakor saw it all... three thousand years ago...
I just wanted to say that I appreciate what you did on the Defiant. I hope it won't cause you too much trouble when you get back to Cardassia.
My superiors in the science ministry will protect me. Frankly, I think Dejar is in a lot more trouble than I am. The Order doesn't reward failure.
Still... it was a very brave thing to do.
I didn't want you to take the blame for something that wasn't your fault. I know how proud you are of your work.
Sometimes too proud. It's gotten me into trouble now and again.
What's your wife's name?
Keiko.
Keiko... A lucky woman.
Good-bye, Mister O'Brien.
Emissary... I'm sorry I doubted you. I realize now that I let my distrust of the Cardassians blind me to the Prophets' words.
It seems that the Prophets want peace between your two peoples after all.
Perhaps so...
There are signs that Trakor's fourth prophecy will soon come to pass as well...
Don't tell me it has something to do with me...
You, Commander? Well... it is a prophecy about the Emissary...
Tell me about it.
The fourth prophecy says that the Emissary will face a fiery trial... and that he will be forced to choose between --
First Officer's Log, Stardate 48521.5. Odo and I are returning to Deep Space Nine after reviewing security procedures at Prophet's Landing, the Bajoran Colony closest to the Cardassian Border.
Those orbital sensor platforms should give the colonists plenty of advanced warning in case the Cardassians ever decide to violate the new treaty.
Hopefully.
How did your meeting with Security Chief Bemar go?
Fine.
I assume he was properly impressed by the depth of your expertise.
Odo, is something bothering you?
What makes you say that?
For one thing, you haven't said more than five words to me since we left Prophet's Landing.
Look, if I've done something to offend you I wish you'd tell me what it is.
It's nothing.
No. It's something. So you might as well talk about it. It might make you feel better.
Nevermind. Forget I asked.
It's not important.
Whatever you say.
It's certainly not worth making an issue about.
I'm glad to hear it.
It's just... when Governor Avesta invited us to dinner at his house...
Go on.
You said no.
And?
You never bothered to ask me if I wanted to go.
You wanted to go to dinner at the governor's house?
Not particularly.
Then what's the problem?
The problem is... you never asked what I wanted.
I'm sorry... I just thought that you wouldn't want to go.
How could you know for certain if you never asked?
Odo... you don't eat! Besides, you hate socializing with people you don't know.
That's beside the point. I would've liked to have been consulted, that's all.
You're right. Next time we're invited to dinner, I'll let you be the one to say no.
I'd appreciate that.
Hold on, I'm picking up a wide band subspace transmission from a Lissepian supply ship. They were just attacked by a Maquis interceptor.
Long range sensors are detecting a modified Peregrine Class courier ship, lightly armed, one man crew, bearing two-six-eight mark three-oh- one.
The Maquis use Peregrine Class courier ships. The Lissepians didn't sustain any serious damage. I'm going after him.
Right.
O'Brien to Sisko.
Go ahead.
Commander, there's... someone here to see you.
Who is it?
(can't believe it himself) It's... Nog, sir.
Nog.
Tell him it's urgent.
He says it's urgent.
Send him in.
I told you he'd see me.
Commander, first let me express my most sincere thanks for allowing me to speak with you.
You're welcome. Now what's this all about?
I wanted to give you... this.
Open it.
What's this?
It's latinum.
I know it's latinum. Why are you giving it to me?
Yesterday I completed the Ferengi Attainment Ceremony. I'm an adult.
Congratulations.
Thank you.
But that still doesn't explain this.

It's my life's savings. According to Ferengi Bylaws, section one-oh- five, subparagraph ten, upon reaching adulthood, Ferengi males must purchase an apprenticeship from a suitable role model. I choose you.
You want to be my apprentice?
That's right. I want to be the first Ferengi in Starfleet. Now who do I see about getting a uniform?
Nog, I'm afraid it doesn't work that way. We don't just give Starfleet uniforms to anyone.
I understand.
But a man of your stature could undoubtedly arrange something. One day, I plan on being a commander just like you.
Nog, if you want to be a Starfleet Officer, you have to attend the Academy.
(thinks about it for a beat) All right. Where do I sign up?
It's not that simple. As a non- Federation citizen, you need a letter of reference from a command level officer before you can even take the entrance exam.
A command level officer? You mean, like you?
Yes. Like me.
Perfect. Is it a form letter or would you like me to help you write it?
Tell me Nog... why do you want to join Starfleet? Why not serve aboard a Ferengi ship?
Are you saying that, as a Ferengi, I'm not good enough to join Starfleet?
Not at all.
Then you'll write the letter.
I'll think about it.
Thank you, Commander. I know you'll make the right decision.
Hold on.
Aren't you forgetting something?
Keep it. Consider it a token of my appreciation.
I don't know what the Maquis have done to that ship's engines, but it's fast.
Not fast enough. We're closing on him.
We'd better catch him soon. We're entering the Badlands.
Clever. He probably knows this territory a lot better than we do.
Now aren't you glad I didn't accept that dinner invitation. If I had, we would've missed all this excitement.
That would've been a pity. Wait a minute... I've lost him. The Badlands' plasma fields are disrupting our sensors.
Increase the sensor bandwidth. That should compensate for the interference.
I hope you're right.
He couldn't have gotten far. He's probably somewhere in this solar system.
There he is. It looks like he's headed for one of the moons orbiting that gas giant.
I'm following him in.
Something's wrong with his ship. It looks like his attitude stabilizers have failed.
Can we get a transporter lock on him?
There's too much interference.
He's trying to land on that moon.
We've lost him.
Did he make it?
I don't know. Something in the moon's atmosphere is jamming our sensors.
Then I guess we'll have to land and see for ourselves.
The tricorders are useless. The atmospheric ionization is jamming their transponders.
You're sure he's in these caverns?
He wasn't in the wreckage of his ship. And given the weather conditions on the surface, there's no way anyone could survive out there very long. So that leaves...
That's the third quake since we landed. This moon must be seismically unstable.
The sooner we find our fugitive, the better off we'll be.

Finding him isn't going to be easy. These caverns could go on forever. And given all this seismic activity, I don't want to stay here any longer than we have to. I say we split up. We can meet back here in twenty minutes. If we haven't found him by then, we may have to leave without him.
If he's smart, he'll let us find him. A Federation prison would be paradise compared to this place.
Let's hope he's smart.
I'll see you in twenty minutes.
Kira to Odo. Odo, do you hear me?
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: This is Odo. I can barely hear you.
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: Odo, I'm trapped and I need your help. Come quickly. Odo, do you read me? This is Kira...
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: Stay where you are, Major. I'll be right there.
scene: 11   INT. ANOTHER PART OF THE CAVERN

quote: Odo... Odo is that you?
I'm right here, Major.
Odo, am I glad to see you.
What's wrong?
You're not going to believe this... my foot is stuck.
Stuck? (makes his way over to her) How?
I don't know. I must've stepped into a fissure or something. I can't get it loose.
Let me take a look.
It's not a fissure.
Then what is it?
Your foot's been encased in some kind of crystal. And from the look of things...
The crystal's spreading.
You're sure you can't pull it loose?
Believe me, I've tried.
Maybe if you slipped your foot out of your boot.
I can barely feel my foot, the crystal is pressing against it so hard. There's no way I can get my boot off.
Hold on.
This might hurt a little.
Go ahead.
I fail to see the humor in this situation.
Oh come on, Odo. You have to admit, it's pretty ridiculous. The two of us outsmarted by a chunk of crystal.
I'm not giving up just yet.
Neither am I. Hand me my phaser.
It's over there. By the palm beacon.
You're sure this is a good idea? If you're not careful...
I'll blow my foot off and Julian will have a chance to prove what a wonderful doctor he is. Don't worry, I have no intention of giving him the opportunity. Now stand back.
I guess that wasn't a very good idea after all.
The crystal formation seems to have somehow fed off the energy from the phaser.
Odo to Mekong. Two to beam out. Energize.
Odo to Mekong. I can't contact the runabout. There's too much interference. I'll have to walk back to the landing site and try to transport you from there.
You're worried about leaving me here?
Now that you mention it, yes.
I'll be fine, Odo. I promise not to go anywhere.
What about our Maquis fugitive?
If he shows up, I'll make sure he waits here until you get back.
Nog, hand me that phase matrix recalibrator.
Here you are, Father.
Is it fixed yet?
Not yet, Brother.
What's taking so long?
We're working as fast as we can. The replicators' entire power supply grid has been shorted out.
I told you, Brother, if you don't shut down your replicators at least once a week for routine maintenance, you risk system overloads like this one.
You said it "might" overload the system. "Might."
He tried to warn you, Uncle Quark. You should've listened to him.
No. It's my fault. I should have explained it better.
Of course it's your fault. Everything that goes wrong here is your fault. It says so in your contract. This mess better be cleaned up before lunchtime or I'm taking the losses out of your pay.
Of course, Brother.
I need to get a replacement power coupling from the storeroom. I'll be right back.
Hey, Nog. What's going on?
If you're here to order lunch, you'll have to come back in an hour.
Actually, I just ate. Hey, that was a pretty funny joke you pulled on my Dad this morning. (off Nog's questioning look) You know, about wanting to join Starfleet.
Come on, Nog. You don't really expect me to fall for that one.
Did you tell your father I was joking?
Yeah, kind of.
How could you do that to me? I want you to go back to your father and tell him that you were wrong.
All right. Take it easy. I mean how was I supposed to know you were serious? You never said you wanted to join Starfleet before.
I'm saying it now.
So what brought this on?
I have my reasons.
Okay. Name one.
Why should I?
Cause I'm your friend. And friends don't have secrets from one another.
It isn't a secret. I just don't want to talk about it.
Why not?
Because it's personal. Now stop asking me.
All right. But my father's a pretty smart guy. If this is some kind of trick, he's going to figure it out.
There's nothing to figure out. I'm going to join Starfleet. And that's that. (looks back at the replicator) Now if you don't mind, I have work to do.
Computer, lock onto these coordinates and initiate transport sequence.
Unable to comply.
Explain.
The high level of atmospheric ionization is inhibiting transporter lock.
Can you compensate for the interference by using pattern enhancers?
Negative. Pattern enhancers will not function in a polarized ionization field.
Is there any way to achieve a transporter lock in this kind of ionization field?
Negative.
Computer, send out a priority one distress signal to Deep Space Nine.
Unable to comply. Communications systems are inoperable due to atmospheric interference.
In that case, launch a communications probe and instruct it to begin a continuous broadcast of our whereabouts as soon as it clears the atmosphere.
Working.
Probe launch confirmed.
Computer, given ideal conditions, how soon can we expect help from Deep Space Nine?
Deep Space Nine should receive the probe's distress signal in approximately two days.
Kira... I heard phaser fire.
You just missed our friend. He came out of that tunnel. I think he was as surprised as I was. He fired at me from over there, but when I shot back he ran off down the tunnel.
Don't worry, his aim wasn't any better than mine was.
He didn't miss by much.
This must be my lucky day.
I see you've put in a request to reassign Ensign Vilix'pran from Cargo Inspection.
I thought it'd be for the best. Given his condition, I don't want him coming in contact with any hazardous materials.
His condition?
Ensign Vilix'pran is budding. The buds will be undergoing individuation in a little over a month.
You mean... he's pregnant?
Twins.
Reassignment granted. I'll have to offer the ensign my congratulations the next time I see him.
O'Brien and I are throwing him a baby shower in a couple of days. I'm sure it'd mean a lot to him if you were there.
Are you getting him anything?
O'Brien's building him a hatchling pond and I've already placed an order with Garak for some baby clothes.
Count me in.
Commander Sisko.
If you'll excuse me, Doctor?
By all means.
So, Commander, have you made up your mind yet? About my letter?
Not exactly.
What does that mean, "not exactly?"
Look, Nog, I have to be honest with you, when I think of candidates for Starfleet Academy, yours is not the first name that comes to mind.
Why not? Because I'm a Ferengi?
Not at all. The fact is, your reputation on this station leaves a lot to be desired. Your school grades are mediocre at best, you've had more than a few run-ins with Constable Odo...
Okay, I've made some mistakes. I admit that. But I can do better. Just give me a chance.
You wanted to see me, Benjamin?
Lieutenant, I need a complete inventory on the contents of Cargo Bay Twelve.
Didn't we inventory Twelve last week?
I'd like it done again.
All right. I'll assign a crew to it immediately.
Actually, I already have someone in mind for the job.
Really? Who?
Nog.
Nog?
He's asked for a recommendation to Starfleet Academy.
Nog.
My reaction exactly.
I've always thought it would be interesting to have a Ferengi in Starfleet, but Nog?
I know it seems unlikely, but before I make up my mind, I want to give him a chance to prove himself.
Commander, there's a lot of valuable equipment in Cargo Bay Twelve.
I know.
Maybe I'd better assign a couple of crewmembers to... assist him.
No. I want him to do it alone. No help. No interference. And no one looking over his shoulder.
I wish I could analyze this material.
Too bad our tricorders don't work.
Or our communicators... or the transporter. Our fugitive couldn't have picked a better place to hide. Very convenient, don't you think?
You make it sound like he planned on trapping us.
Maybe he did. But it's not going to work. I'm going to get you out of here.
How much longer do you think I have, Odo?
Long enough.
I figure if the crystal keeps growing at its current rate, it'll cover me completely in less than twelve hours.
Unless this cave collapses first.
(his frustration leaking through) There has to be a way to shatter the crystal.
I'm sure there is. But that doesn't mean that we're going to find it in the next twelve hours.
We'll find it.
Odo, maybe you should go back to Deep Space Nine.
We're too far away. Even if they sent a rescue team right now, they'd never make it here in time.
Maybe not, but there's no point in both of us being buried here.
You mean you want me to leave?
You've done all you can.
Major, I haven't even begun yet.
Oh, I see. So everything you've done up until now has only been... a warmup exercise.
(trying to raise her spirits) Exactly. I've just been lulling this crystal into a false sense of security.
I think it's working.
Major, do you ever look at the Criminal Activity Reports we get from Starfleet Security?
Not often.
You should. They make fascinating
So all we have to do is find some Nausicaan raiders and ask them to give us a hand.

I might be able to put together a makeshift generator using the covariant oscillator from the runabout. The trick will be finding the right frequency to create a sympathetic vibration inside this crystal. I'll have to go back to the runabout and start assembling the generator. Keep your phaser ready in case our friend comes back.
I will.
I'll be back as soon as I can.
Constable. When we get back to the station, I'm going to start reading those Criminal Activity Reports.
I'll make sure you get them.
Due to a computer error, we lost the manifest on this entire cargo bay. Commander Sisko would like you to re- inventory the contents.
Of the entire cargo bay?
That's right.
By myself?
Look Nog, Starfleet isn't only about exploration and diplomacy. A lot of the time, it's just hard work.
When does Commander Sisko want it done?
He'd like the manifest on his desk first thing tomorrow morning.
He'll have it tonight, before he goes off duty.
Tomorrow morning will be fine.
Now if you don't mind, Lieutenant, I'd like to get started.
What's wrong?
It's getting a little snug in here, that's all.
How long do you think it'll take the generator to find the right frequency?
It's hard to say. It could take hours.
I don't suppose there's any way to speed things up?
I didn't think so.
Don't worry, Major. I have every intention of getting us back to the station by tomorrow night. Chief O'Brien is counting on it.
What does O'Brien have to do with it?
(doesn't want to get into it) We have... an appointment.
What kind of appointment?
Talk to me, Odo. It'll help pass the time.
The Chief and I are supposed to go kayaking together... in a holosuite.
You're kidding. How did he talk you into that?
He didn't talk me into anything. It's really quite enjoyable.
You mean you've done it before?
Twice. He invited me one evening and, seeing I had no other plans, I accepted.
I'm sorry. I'm just having a little trouble picturing you and O'Brien together in a boat.
Well if it helps any, he's the one who does all the singing.
He sings?
He says it's necessary to establish a smooth paddling rhythm.
This gets better and better. What kind of songs does he sing?
Ancient human sea chanties, mostly. He's particularly fond of one called "Louie, Louie."
I never knew O'Brien was so... nautical.
Next to his work and his family, "shooting the rapids" is his favorite activity. He's had the holo-program since he was on the Enterprise.
So how long do these boat trips usually take?
That depends.
On what?
On how many times we capsize. The truth is, Major, Chief O'Brien's never completed the entire program.
Not once?
Not in seven years of trying.
It must be a very difficult program.
Extremely difficult. According to him, he's dislocated his shoulder a half dozen times trying to make it down those rapids.
Then why does he keep doing it?
Because he loves it. And it's been my observation that you humanoids have a hard time giving up the things you love... no matter how much they might hurt you.
I should check the equipment.
The equipment's fine. I'm glad you're here, Odo.
I'm glad I'm here, too.
(alarmed, reacting to what she sees) Odo...
Major?
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I'm all right. What about the generator?
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: It's fine. But it still hasn't found the right frequency to shatter the crystal.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Tell it to hurry. A few more tremors like that last one and this whole cave will collapse.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Then we'll have to make sure we're not here when that happens. After all, we've been in worse situations than this one and come out all right.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: Name three.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I can't think of any either.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: It's not that. It's just... That wasn't the response I expected.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: What do you mean?
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: In the detective novels Chief O'Brien gives me to read, when the hero says, "We've been in tougher scrapes than this one," his friends always agree.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I never read any of those books.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: There must be some humanoid platitude I can use to cheer you up.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I'm afraid I don't have much use for platitudes, Odo. I'd rather just face the truth about a situation and go on from there.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I feel the same way.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I know.That's why you and I get along so well.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I suppose it is. But in this case, the truth is we are going to get you out of here, Major. And that's no platitude.
scene: 39   INT. CAVERN CHAMBER - CLOSE ON KIRA

quote: I have to admit, this is impressive work.
Incredible is more like it. He inventoried the whole cargo bay in under five hours.
You're sure he didn't have any help?
According to the internal sensors, no one else entered that cargo bay for the entire time he was there.
I guess he learned a few things working in his uncle's storeroom. (trying to put it delicately) I assume all our equipment is still... where it's supposed to be?
If you're asking if he stole anything, the answer is no. He even found some items we missed during our last inventory.
Okay, so we know he's a hard worker, but the question remains: Why does he want to join Starfleet?
I have no idea.
So we still can't be sure if he's serious or if this is all part of some elaborate scam.
Commander, we need to talk.
Go right ahead.
It's about my nephew.
Somehow, I'm not surprised.
Rom, tell Commander Sisko what's on your mind.
Well, the thing is... I'm not quite sure...
What my brother's trying to say is he's furious that you'd even consider allowing his son to attend Starfleet Academy. Isn't that right?
Well, I...
You see. He can barely speak he's so angry. Now we... I mean, he... demands you refuse the boy's request and return his latinum immediately.
Rom, is that what you want?
The thing is... we've always assumed... that is... I did promise that Nog would become... my brother's apprentice...
That explains things.
Lieutenant, please, this is between my brother and Commander Sisko.
Actually, that's not true. Your... brother's feelings aren't at issue here. According to both Federation law and Ferengi tradition, Nog is old enough to make his own decisions.
You see, brother, I told you.
And as for the latinum, must I remind you of the first Rule of Acquisition?
"Once you have their money, you never give it back." It's one of my brother's favorites. Isn't that so, Brother?
I'm not going to stand here and argue Rules of Acquisition with a human.
Especially one who knows them as well as you.
(ignoring her, to Sisko) That apprenticeship money is rightfully mine. And I will protest your actions to the Nagus himself if I have to.
Give the Nagus my best.
Can we leave now, brother?
Would you stop calling me that?
Calling you what?
"Brother."
But you are my brother. Unless mother lied to us.
If only that were true.
So I take it you are going to write Nog's letter of recommendation?
I don't know. That depends on Nog.

I don't understand it. I've run through the entire harmonic spectrum and none of the frequencies have had an effect on the crystal. It's almost as if the structure of the crystal is mutating to keep us from finding the right frequency.
Odo.
Yes, Major.
I wish there was something else I could do...
Just keep talking to me.
What do you want me to say?
Anything. Tell me a story.
A story?
I know. Tell me how you got your name.
My name? Come to think of it, that is an amusing story.
Tell it to me.

Well, as you know, when Doctor Mora first brought me to his laboratory, it was under Cardassian supervision. All specimens had to be clearly labeled in Cardassian, so that the overseers would always know what the scientists were working on. Since no one could decide exactly what I was, Mora labelled me "Unknown Sample," which the overseer translated into Cardassian as "Odo'ital."
So your name is "Unknown Sample?"

No. "Odo'ital" literally means "Nothing." Even after it became clear that I was sentient, the Bajoran scientists kept calling me that. As a joke, they split it into two words, like a Bajoran name: "Odo Ital." Which eventually got shortened...
To Odo.

But the thing is, for the longest time, when anyone spoke my name, the first thing I'd think of was what it meant: "Nothing." What better way to describe me? I had no family, no friends, no place where I belonged.
I thought it was the most appropriate name anyone could give me. And then I met you...
And the others. Sisko, Dax, even Quark. And now, when I hear one of you call me "Odo," I no longer think of myself as "Nothing." I think of myself as... me.
I'm sorry, Major. I guess that story wasn't as amusing as I'd hoped it would be.
No. I liked it very much.
The ultrasonic generator isn't going to work, is it?
No, I'm afraid it's not.
I don't suppose you have any other ideas.
I wish I had.
If it makes you feel better, I don't have any either.
It just doesn't make sense. The ultrasonic generator should have worked. Something's not right here.
Odo, you've done your best. Now I think it's time for you to go.
Go?
This place could collapse at any minute. That Maquis has probably been killed already by one of the cave-ins. There's nothing more you can do for me.
If you're asking me to leave...
No. I know you wouldn't listen to me.
You're right about that.
So as your superior officer, I'm telling you to take the runabout and get the hell off this moon. That's an order.
Odo, what are you standing there for? I told you to get out of here.
I'm not leaving.
Constable, I gave you a direct order.
You can order me all you want. As of now, I'm resigning my commission.
Odo, if you stay here, you'll die.
You don't know that for certain. And even if it were true, I'm not going to abandon you.
But I want you to go.
Don't you understand? I can't.
You have to.
Please, Odo.
No. I won't leave you.
Why not?
Because... Because, I'm in love with you.
So now you know.
Odo...
I'm in love with you, too.
You wanted to see me, Commander?
Nog I've given your request a lot of thought.
I appreciate that, Commander.
But I'm afraid I have to turn you down.
Turn me down? Why? Did I do something wrong?
It's not anything you did, Nog. You're just not Academy material.
Here. This belongs to you.
Commander, can't we talk about this?
There's nothing to talk about. We both know you'd never make it through the Academy. You couldn't handle the workload or the discipline. You wouldn't last two weeks.
That's not true. I'm a hard worker. I proved that to you.
It doesn't matter. I'm not going to place my reputation on the line just to satisfy some whim of yours.
It's not just a whim. I'm serious about joining Starfleet.
I don't have time for this, Nog. Whatever little scheme you had, you can forget it. You're not getting that letter.
It's not a joke... or a scheme. I want to join Starfleet. I want it more than I've ever wanted anything in my life.
You're a Ferengi. Why would you want to be in Starfleet? Where's the profit in it?
I don't care about profit.
Then what do you care about? Come on, Nog, tell me. Why is it so damned important for you to get into Starfleet? Why are you doing this?
(finally blurts out the truth) Because I don't want to end up like my father.
Your father.
That's right. My father. He's been chasing after profit his whole life. And what has it gotten him? Nothing. And you know why? Because he doesn't have the lobes. And neither do I.
And "A Ferengi without profit... "
"... Is no Ferengi at all."
The eighteenth Rule of Acquisition.

My father's a mechanical genius. He could've been the chief engineer of a starship if he'd had the opportunity. But he went into business instead, like a good Ferengi. The only thing is, he's not a good Ferengi... not when it comes to acquiring profit. So now all he has to live for is the slim chance that someday, somehow, he might be able to take over my uncle's bar. Well I'm not going to make the same mistake. I want to do something with my life... something worthwhile.
Like joining Starfleet.
I might not have an instinct for business, but I've got my father's hands and my uncle's tenacity. I know I've got something to offer, I just need a chance to prove it.
All right. I'll see to it you get that chance.
You'll recommend me to Starfleet Academy?
I'll send the letter first thing tomorrow morning.
Commander, I don't know how to thank you.
Don't thank me yet. You've got a lot of work ahead of you.
Don't worry. You'll never regret this.
Odo?
Yes, Major.
You haven't said a word in almost an hour.
I've just been going over a few things in my mind.
You've been thinking about me, haven't you?
I'm sorry that it took so long for me to tell you how I feel about you. Maybe if I'd told you earlier, things would've been different.
What are you smiling about?

(still looking at the phaser hits) I think I've finally figured out what's going on here. This whole situation hasn't seemed right since the beginning. There've been too many coincidences, too many unanswered questions.
Are you still trying to prove this is some kind of conspiracy?
You said the Maquis was standing about here when he fired at you?
That's right.
How tall was he? My height?
No. Maybe a little shorter.
Like this?
More or less. Why does it matter anyway?
It matters because from this position, you're blocking those phaser hits.
There's no way someone standing here could've hit those rocks without hitting you first.
Maybe he was standing somewhere else.
Maybe. Or maybe you were lying to me. Which makes two times you've lied to me today.
What are you talking about?
You lied when you said you were shot at by the Maquis. And you lied when you said you loved me.

I wish you did. But you don't. Remember Major, I pride myself on my ability to observe human nature. And I've watched you for the past three years. In all that time, I never saw the slightest indication that you had those kinds of feelings for me. You like me. You think of me as a close friend... but love? I'm afraid not.
Maybe I said I loved you because I thought it'd make you feel better. Because I thought it was what you wanted to hear.
You're lying again. The Kira I know values our friendship far too much to lie to me, even for the best of reasons.
Odo... I can explain...
Good. You can start by telling me who you are and what you've done with Kira.
Well done, Odo. You really are quite a skillful investigator.
And you're quite a skillful changeling.
You still have much to learn.
If you want to share your wisdom with me, you can start by telling me where Major Kira is.
Close by.
You were the fugitive we were chasing, weren't you?
That's correct.
How'd you get your hands on a Maquis ship?
Now, Odo, you can't expect me to give you all the answers.
But why did you lead us here? And why replace Kira?
I needed to understand why you chose to live with the Solids rather than your own people. I suspected it had something to do with Major Kira. And now I'm certain of it.
So your plan was to let me think she died. You thought that would take away my link to the Solids.
And then you would return to us.
I assure you, nothing will ever make me do that.
I wouldn't be so sure.
(still aiming the phaser) Tell me where she is.
And if I don't, then what? You'll shoot me? No changeling has ever harmed another.
There's a first time for everything.
Major Kira is down that tunnel, two hundred meters south of here. Save her if it suits you. But it won't make any difference. She's never going to love you. How could she? You're a changeling.
Major. Wake up.
Odo, what happened? How did I get here...
It's a long story. Right now we have to get you to the Mekong.
There's one thing I still don't understand. If that Founder wanted to test your allegiance to the Solids, why did she impersonate me?
I suppose it's because you happened to be with me in the runabout. It could just as easily have been Commander Sisko... or Doctor Bashir.
So what finally made you realize the truth?
Eventually she made a mistake. She said something I know you would never say.
And what was that?
Just a slip of the tongue. Nothing important.
I tell you, I won't stand for it. No nephew of mine is going to disgrace our family name by joining Starfleet.
But Uncle Quark...
My mind is made up. I forbid it.
No you don't.
Rom, stay out of this.
I will not. When it comes to the bar, you may be in charge, but when it comes to my son, I make the decisions.
Then you tell him he can't go.
I'll do no such thing.
What?
Nog. Good luck. I would be proud to have a son in Starfleet.
You're both insane.
Like father, like son.
O'Brien to Sisko.
Go ahead.
We've swept all of Level Seventeen. No sign of the changeling.
Move down to Eighteen. We'll meet you there after we finish checking the guest quarters.
Just watch yourself, Chief. This changeling knows the station as well as we do. He could be anywhere... or anything.
Aye, Major.
We found him. He's headed for the Promenade.
All right, I want phaser sweeps of everything in the Promenade. He's here somewhere. Let's find him. On three. One, two...
Bang. You're dead.
And so is Doctor Bashir.
Computer, elapsed time?
Three hours, twenty-seven minutes.
That's not good enough. If one of my people were loose on the station for that long, there's no telling what damage he could do.
Schedule another surprise drill. If the Dominion tries to infiltrate the station, I want to be ready for them.
And remind everyone that next time, they'd better sweep everything. A changeling can be anything. A post, a pillar... Even a patch of reflective surfacing.
We get the message, Constable.
I hope so, Chief. Just remember, the Founders are even better shape-shifters than I am.
Excuse me, but if you're done scaring my customers away, I'd like to reopen the bar.
Go right ahead.

Thank you. Constable, it just occurred to me that if I knew in advance how long it would take them to catch you during the next drill... Well let's just say you and I could split a substantial profit.
Think about it.
Performance reviews will be held starting at oh-eight-hundred hours tomorrow in the wardroom. Check with your team leader for the schedule. Dismissed.
How about some dinner?
Not tonight. I've got a previous engagement.
Oh, that's right. Captain Yates got in this morning. Give her my regards.
I will.
Come in.
Hello, Ben. I hope I'm not too late.
Some things are worth waiting for.
Nice.
I'm glad you like it.
Here. For you.
Isn't that a coincidence? I have something for you, too.
(reacting to the scarf, delighted) Where'd you find Tholian silk?
The Tholian ambassador owed me a favor.
May I?
It's not silk, but I think you'll like it.
It's from my brother's team.
The Pike City Pioneers.
My brother says if you're ever on Cestus Three, he'll get you seats in the dugout.
How far is it to Cestus Three?
Eight weeks, at maximum warp.
To see a real baseball game... might be worth the trip.
Tell you what, if you ever decide to go, I'll take you there myself. As long as you don't mind traveling by freighter.
I might just take you up on that.
Did you do this all yourself?
My father always says the way to a woman's heart is through her stomach.
Ah, so it's my heart you're after.
I never could keep a secret.
In that case, maybe you could tell me what all those maintenance crews are doing in the docking ring.
Just some retrofitting.
Now you are keeping a secret.
Let's just say we're preparing a few surprises in case the Dominion comes through the wormhole.
Seems like everyone's got the Dominion on their minds these days. I hear the Cardassians have even sealed their borders.
They're worried about being infiltrated by the Dominion.
The idea that there might be changelings loose in the Alpha Quadrant has everyone a little nervous.

All I know is I've got a cargo hold full of Teresian hardwood bound for Cardassia Prime and now I can't deliver it. If you ask me, I think everyone's being a little paranoid. (looks to Sisko for confirmation) Aren't they?
I hope so. (doesn't want to talk about it) What do you say we forget about business for a while?
I'd say that's a good idea.
Dax to Sisko.
Go ahead.
I think you'd better get up here.
On my way. I'll be back as soon as I can.
I know you will.
It just decloaked.
That's the new Klingon flagship.
The Negh'Var. There's a General Martok aboard, asking to speak with you.
Put him through.
Captain Sisko. I bring greetings from your allies in the Klingon Empire.
Welcome to Deep Space Nine, General. Is there something I can do for you?
It has been a long journey. My men require shore leave.
Certainly. They can come aboard whenever they like.
Good.
Sowee TAH!
Chief, I'm beginning to think there's no limit to the wonders you can perform.
That's what I like about you, Julian. You're easily impressed.
Thank you, Quark. Can we get a little yamok sauce for these sand peas?
(trying to get his attention) Quark?
Listen. Do you hear that?
I don't hear a thing.
Exactly. The ambient noise level in this room is less than thirty decibels. On an average day it's sixty-five. When there're Klingons in the room, it can go as high as eighty-five.
So what you're saying is, it's quiet in here.
Too quiet. Something is terribly wrong.
Like what?
I don't know. But have you ever met a quiet Klingon before? And look at the way they're watching the room. It's like... they're picking out targets.
Where are you going?
I thought I'd ask the Klingons what they're up to.
Don't do that.
Why not?
I don't want them to know we're on to them.
Suit yourself.
The secret is positioning the pea correctly on your hand.
I thought I did.
What are you two doing? I'm telling you, the Klingons are up to something.
Calm down, Quark. The Klingons are our allies.
They might be your allies, but they're not mine.
Relax. If something's up with the Klingons, Captain Sisko will find out about it.
Yeah. But will he tell me?
So what brings you here, General?
A valid question. But first ...
Let us be sure we are all who we say we are.
You think we're changelings?
What I think doesn't matter. The blood will tell.
(still waiting for his answer) Now that that's over with...
We've been sent here to fight alongside our Federation allies against the Dominion.
I appreciate the gesture. But I'm not sure it's necessary.
The Klingon High Council thinks it is.
Our communications relay in the Gamma Quadrant hasn't detected any signs of Jem'Hadar activity for quite some time. They seem to be giving the wormhole a wide berth.
They will come. And when they do, we will be ready for them.
There you are. We've been looking all over for you. Malko here just gave me an amazing massage. I'm sure if you ask nicely he'd be willing to do the same for you.
No thanks.
Why?
Because Malko isn't real. He's a puppet made of holographic light and replicated matter.
Boys, can you wait outside?
Afraid I hurt their feelings?
You really should try to get into the spirit of things. People come from all over Trill to visit the Hoobishan Baths.
And if I'm ever on Trill I'll visit them too. But we're not on Trill and this isn't the Hoobishan Baths. It's a holosuite. Nothing here is real.
And?
I'm sorry Dax. I just feel... silly.
Good. That's what a holosuite's for. To have a good time. All you have to do is relax and use your imagination.
I guess I don't have much of an imagination.
Of course you do. Everyone does. Didn't you used to play make- believe when you were a kid?
Yeah. I used to make-believe that all the Cardassians would stop killing Bajorans and just go away.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean--
No. I'm the one who's sorry. I guess I've never gotten much use out of my imagination. I mean, look at me. You planned a fun evening for us and all I can do is sit here and worry about Klingons.
You can worry about them tomorrow. From what I hear, they aren't going anywhere. And as for your underdeveloped imagination, I prescribe a strict regimen of exercise... starting immediately.
All right, I'll give it a try.
That's all I ask. Come on. Malko couldn't have gotten far.
Fascinating. So both the cup and the liquid are merely extensions of your body.
That's correct. And if I want to, I can even drink the liquid, reabsorb it, and produce new "coffee" in the cup.
This way I can give the illusion that I'm sharing in the dining experience.
Very thoughtful.
So, perhaps you'd like to tell me what's bothering you?
Why do you think something's bothering me?
Because you're almost done with your meal. It usually takes you twice as long to eat your breakfast.
Does it?
In my experience, most mornings you're more interested in talking than eating.
Maybe I'm just hungry today.
Tell me, Odo, have you heard any news from Cardassia lately?
Not since they sealed their borders.
Well I have. And frankly I don't like what I've been hearing. Rumors of uprisings, civil disturbances. All very alarming.
I didn't know you still had friends inside the Empire.
One or two. But now I can't even get through to them. I'm worried. With the destruction of the Obsidian Order and the threat of the Dominion, these are unsettling times for Cardassia.
They're unsettling times for everyone. But, if I hear anything, I'll let you know.
I'd appreciate that, Constable.
Excuse me a moment.
So what is it that you do on this station?
May I help you?
Lohd Zoss-lee chaw-KU sohk jaTAL? (Does your mother let you talk to men?)
Actually, I'm not sure Constable Odo has a mother.
Morn, I believe Ensign Sanders is looking for you.
Gentlemen, if you have business on the Promenade, I suggest you go about it. If not, move along.
I'd listen to him if I were you.
I don't take orders from Shape-shifters. Or their Cardassian lapdogs.
I may be a Shape-shifter, but I'm also chief of security of this station. So either you move along, or you'll be continuing this conversation from inside a holding cell.
As long as you wear that Bajoran uniform, we're allies. Make sure you never take it off.
(talking to Garak, but his eyes still on Drex) I didn't know you spoke Klingon.
You'd be surprised at the kind of things you can learn while you're doing alterations.
Let me guess, you're either lost or you're desperately searching for a good tailor.
Guess again.
I can't believe you're not pressing charges.
Constable Odo and Captain Sisko expressed similar concern. But really, Doctor, there was no harm done.
They broke seven of your transverse ribs and fractured your clavicle.
But I got off several cutting remarks that no doubt did serious damage to their egos.
Garak, it's not funny.

I'm serious, Doctor. Thanks to your ministrations, I'm almost completely healed. The damage I did to them will last a lifetime. What I can't understand is their inexplicable hostility toward me. Maligning Constable Odo is one thing... after all he is a changeling and the Klingons don't know him as well as we do. But relations between the Klingon and Cardassian Empires have never been anything but amicable.
With the exception of the Betreka Nebula incident.
A minor skirmish.
That lasted eighteen years.
That was ages ago. Maybe they decided they just didn't like me?
Not like you? Impossible.
You're right, as always, Doctor. They must've mistaken me for someone else.
The Klingon ships keep cloaking and decloaking, so it's impossible to get an exact count, but so far, we've been able to identify at least twenty different warships in the vicinity of the station.
Captain, we're receiving a priority one distress call from the freighter Xhosa.
Kasidy's ship?
She left the station an hour ago. Put her through.
This is the freighter Xhosa to Deep Space Nine. We're under attack by--
Her signal's been jammed.
Get me a fix on her location. Then tell the crew of the Defiant to man their stations. We'll meet you on the bridge.
Forward scanners are detecting the Xhosa at bearing zero-one-seven mark three-four-six.
I'm picking up another ship. It's got the Xhosa in a tractor beam.
On screen.
A Klingon ship.
I can't get through to Kasidy. They must be jamming her communications.
Hail the Klingon vessel.
This is Commander Kaybok of the M'Char. What is it you want?
I want to know why you stopped that ship.
We have orders to search all vessels attempting to leave Bajoran space.
Search them for what?
For Shape-shifters. Each ship will be scanned, its cargo searched, and its crewmembers and passengers subjected to genetic testing.
On whose authority?
On the authority of Gowron and the Klingon High Council.
The Klingon High Council has no jurisdiction over ships in Bajoran Space.
We assumed you would welcome our assistance.
Do you have any evidence that there are changelings aboard this particular ship?
How can we have evidence until we conduct our tests?
Commander, Bajoran law strictly prohibits the unwarranted search and seizure of vessels in our territory.
I have my orders.
The Klingon ship has increased power to its tractor beam. It looks like they're preparing to board the Xhosa.
Major, raise shields and power up the forward phasers. See if that gets their attention.
Shields up. Forward phasers standing by.
They're still not releasing the tractor beam.
Fire a warning shot two hundred meters off their starboard bow.
Yes, sir.
Commander Kaybok would like to speak with you.
Let's hear what he has to say.
Captain, this is outrageous.
I agree. But you're not leaving me much choice. You're in violation of Bajoran law. Now I'll ask you one last time... Release that ship immediately.
We are your allies.
Major, lock phasers on the M'Char's engines. Prepare to fire on my command.
Phasers ready.
(on viewscreen, to one of his officers) Kltrek im stram. (Release tractor beam.) Gowron will hear of this.
I'm receiving a hail from the Xhosa. It's Captain Yates.
Put her through.
Captain, I don't know what you said to those Klingons, but it must've been good.
Is everyone all right?
"Everyone" is fine.
I'm glad to hear that.
We'll keep you on sensors as long as possible. But I doubt the Klingons will give you any more trouble.
I appreciate that, Captain. I'll see you in about two weeks.
You know where to find me.
According to our long-range sensors, the Klingon task force has withdrawn to just outside Bajoran territory.
So now they're in unclaimed space. And if they decide to continue searching ships ....
There's nothing we can do about it. Unless they try to stop a Federation or Bajoran vessel.
Which, so far, they haven't done.
Captain, General Martok is here to see you.
Send him in.
General, we need to talk about ...
SOHK-vad.
It's Commander Kaybok's.
Why give it to me?
He's letting you know Kaybok's dead. Martok probably had him executed for disobeying orders.
Which means our next confrontation with the Klingons won't be resolved so easily. Any suggestions, old man?
The longer the Klingons stay here, the worse things are going to get. Whatever you decide to do, you'd better do it soon.
Curzon told me once that in the long run, the only people who can really handle Klingons are Klingons. Get me Starfleet Command.
Dax nods, wondering what Sisko is up to...
Commander Worf.
Chief. It's been a long time.
Too long. Welcome aboard.
Just what this station needs ... another Klingon.
Lieutenant Commander Worf reporting for duty.
It's good to have you aboard, commander.
Thank you, sir.
At ease, Mister Worf.
I was sorry to hear about the Enterprise. She was a good ship.
Yes, sir.
I understand you've been on extended leave ...
I've been visiting the Klingon monastery on Boreth. I found my discussions with the clerics there... most enlightening.
I hope you'll forgive me for pulling you away from your studies. I doubt this assignment will last very long.
My leave was almost over.
Any idea where you're going to be stationed next?
I'm considering resigning my commission.
Really? Do you mind if I ask why?

I've spent most of my life among humans. It has not always been easy for me. And since the destruction of the Enterprise, it has become even more difficult. I am no longer sure I belong in this uniform.
Mister Worf, if I said we didn't need you here, I'd be lying. But if you don't want to take this assignment, I'd understand.
Thank you, sir. But until I make my decision, I intend to do my duty.
I'm glad to hear that. I assume you've read my situation report.
I can't help feeling that General Martok hasn't told me the whole truth about the Klingon task force. There are too many unanswered questions.
Then I will find you some answers.
Good. If you need any help, let me know.
Yes, sir.
Commander.
I thought about resigning from Starfleet once, too. But I know if I had, I would've regretted it. Don't make any quick decisions.
Thank you, sir. I'll keep that in mind.
Let me guess, Klingon bloodwine.
Prune juice, chilled. DEEP SPACE NINE: "Way... Warrior" - REV. 08/01/95 - ACT THREE 37.
Prune juice?
If you say so.
Commander, over here.
Doctor Julian Bashir, Lieutenant Commander Worf.
Care for a game of darts?
I don't play games.
It's like poker, but with pointy tips.
All right, think of it as target practice.
The object is to throw the dart and hit that board over there.
Aim for the dot in the middle.
I can't believe you did that.
He didn't leave me any choice.
What did she do?
She knocked out Lancelot.
He kissed me.
He's supposed to kiss you.
But I was playing a married woman.
Lieutenant Commander Worf, this is Lieutenant Commander Jadzia Dax, and Major Kira Nerys, our first officer.
Nice hat.
I don't always dress like this. We were in the holosuite...
So I gathered. You used to be Curzon Dax.
That's right. And I don't usually dress like this either.
Curzon's name is an honored one among my people.
(mischievous, in Klingon) Louk, a jeek CHIM-ta law. (Yeah, but I'm a lot better looking than he was.)
I suppose so.
